title: About This Site
content:
# About This Site

Hi! I'm Matt Handzel. I'm running an experiment where I'm trying to put the 'personal' in personal website. I want this website to entirely represent who I am, what I care about, how I think, what are my "inputs", and "outputs".

## Why Am I Doing This?

I'm very much into quantified self and I have a fear of posting myself online.

For those that know me, this is a place where you can check in and see how I'm doing
For those that don't know me, this is a place for you to get an authentic understanding of who I am.

## What You Can Find Here

My [habits](https://www.matthandzel.com/dailies), [bucket list](https://www.matthandzel.com/bucket-list), [communities](https://www.matthandzel.com/communities), [books](https://www.matthandzel.com/content-consumed) I've read, and my captured [thoughts](https://www.matthandzel.com/thoughts), ideas, notes.

## How It Works

All content originates from markdown files in my Obsidian vault, which gets processed by Python scripts, stored in a database, and then rendered through atomic React components.

Feel free to explore, interact, and let me know your thoughts at handzelmatthew [at] gmail.com

content:
# Inspiration

---

# Digital gardens / note-graphs

- **Andy Matuschak — evergreen notes / public notebook.** Great example of notes-as-thinking-space (bi-directional links, evergreen notes). ([Andyʼs working notes][1])
  _What to borrow:_ the “notes as UI” approach and minimal metadata for each note.

- **Maggie Appleton — visual digital garden & “historical trails.”** Beautiful visual essays and patterns (good examples of showing journeys & trails through ideas). ([maggieappleton.com][2])
  _What to borrow:_ visual/illustrated essays and the “trail” metaphor for showing where you’ve been intellectually or physically.

- **Joel Hooks — “your friend Joel’s digital garden.”** Clean digital-garden layout + a NOW page. ([joelhooks.com][3])
  _What to borrow:_ simple garden index, tag filters, and a readable “now” summary.

- **Sindhu (sindhu.live) — personal garden + now/guestbook.** Compact, readable garden with a “now” and garden/lore split. ([sindhu.live][4])
  _What to borrow:_ approachable “garden” UI and season/now updates.

# Travel / maps / location timelines

- **Aaron Parecki — GPS logs, “Everywhere I’ve Been” maps, monthly summaries.** Aaron publishes GPS-derived maps and monthly travel summaries — a direct model for your travel timeline/map idea. ([aaronparecki.com][5])
  _What to borrow:_ ingest GPS/GPX logs to build animated “where I was” timelines and monthly map views.

- **Simon Willison — geospatial experiments, mapping infrastructure & examples.** Lots of practical mapping work and demos — useful when you build custom map features (isochrones, map tiles). ([Simon Willison’s Weblog][6])
  _What to borrow:_ pragmatic approach to self-hosting map data and building performant interactive maps.

# Quantified-self / life metrics / dashboards

- **howisFelix.today (Felix Krause) — full personal metrics site.** Tracks \~100 data types (fitness, social, computer use, weather) and visualizes them. Great example of a personal dashboard / life database. ([howisfelix.today][7], [GitHub][8])
  _What to borrow:_ data model for cross-domain metrics and the dashboard layout for asking questions of your life.

- **Maggie Delano — quantified-self projects & reports.** Longstanding QS contributor with projects and data visualizations (pomodoro tracking, talks). ([Maggie Delano][9])
  _What to borrow:_ how to present self-tracking as narrative reports and conference talks.

- **Buster Benson — notes + “life in weeks” and yearly reviews.** Great examples of periodic life reviews and compact visualizations. ([Buster’s Notes][10])
  _What to borrow:_ how to structure annual / weekly retrospectives as shareable pages.

# Now-pages, timelines & “what I’m doing”

- **Aaron Parecki — /now and “monthly summaries” (map + stats).** Simple, machine-friendly now page plus monthly summary with travel map. ([aaronparecki.com][11])
  _What to borrow:_ automated now/monthly pages powered by scripts.

- **Joel Hooks — now + digital-garden entries for narrative timeline feel.** Good for blending “now” with longer-term notes. ([main--joelhooks-com.netlify.app][12])

# Community / memberships / “semantic map of communities”

- **Maggie Appleton — patterns about gatherings & “gathering structures.”** Useful design patterns for visualizing communities and events in context. ([maggieappleton.com][13])
  _What to borrow:_ pattern language for representing communities and events.

- **Rach Smith — accessible digital garden + “month notes & numbers.”** A practical example of a garden that includes periodic summary pages and tags for community topics. ([rachsmith.com][14])

# One-stop collections (to mine more live personal sites)

- **A Digital Garden Inventory (Medium)** — curated list of \~50 real personal digital gardens (handy for finding more live personal sites to copy). ([Medium][15])

---

If you want, next I can do one of these _concrete_ follow-ups (pick one and I’ll run it right now):

1. **Deep dive: top 6 live sites** — take screenshots of the 6 best matches (map, quantified, garden, timeline) and write a 1-paragraph “lift/steal” plan for each (layout + components + minimal tech).
2. **Prototype checklist** — pick 3 live examples and produce a tiny page wireframe (which components go where + data fields to store).
3. **Starter repo** — a minimal Next.js starter that includes: Obsidian markdown import, a simple map page (Leaflet/Mapbox), and a demo quantified-data dashboard (mock data).

Which of those would you like me to do next?

title: Cost Of Context Switching
content:
A study in the book illustrates context-switching costs with a task: write numbers 1–10 in Arabic numerals, Roman numerals, and letters. Doing each set separately is fast. Switching between them slows you down—takes about twice as long.

That’s a huge loss: half your effort is wasted just because of context switching. Across millions of people, that’s a staggering productivity drain.

There’s also a chart: with one project, you have 100% attention and no context-switching loss. Two projects mean 40% per project, 20% loss. With five projects, only 5% per project and 75% is lost. You’re doing more but achieving less.

That doesn’t mean multiple projects are bad. If you're blocked on one, switching can be useful. But this isn't about total efficiency—it’s about knowing the tradeoffs.

title: Sprint
content:
The Sprint is a core idea in Scrum.

- The purpose of a scrim is that you make visible progress as soon as possible and you show it to stakeholders as soon as possible to get [[feedback]]

In sprint planning, tasks are organized into columns like "Backlog," "Doing," "Done," and "Tested." These columns should be tailored to the specific project. Crucially, nothing should be moved to "Done" unless it's usable by the customer.

For example, with Wikispeed, if a car's turn signals are sticking, the related task isn't marked as "Done" until the issue is resolved and the user has verified it.

This implies that for an app, if a user story states they want to see their notes, the application must fully support that before marking the task as complete.

Once sprint tests are defined, nothing should be added mid-sprint. Introducing a new high-priority task during a sprint causes distraction and slows down the team due to context switching and lack of planning.

title: Stand Up Meeting Philosophy
content:
The stand-up should not be treated as a simple status update. Instead, it should function like a football huddle—where team members dynamically coordinate actions to address problems and move toward their goal.

Example from the book: A wide receiver reports an issue with a defensive lineman, prompting a blocker to offer help. The team rapidly adjusts tactics. Similarly, in Scrum, the goal is quick alignment and decisive collaboration.

Passivity in these meetings is not just unproductive; it actively harms team performance. Scrum Masters should address and correct this immediately.

Effective teams leave the meeting knowing the most important task to accomplish next. Collaboration can dramatically speed up work—what one person estimates as a day’s effort might be completed in an hour with help.

title: Stand Up
content:
The daily stand-up is a core Scrum practice, held every day and limited to a maximum of 15 minutes. Its purpose is to align the team and surface any blockers quickly. Three essential questions guide this meeting:

1. What did you do yesterday to help the team finish the sprint?
2. What will you do today to help the team finish the sprint?
3. What obstacles are getting in the team’s way?

There’s a question about whether these three questions are truly optimal. For example, asking “What could have gotten in your way but didn’t?” could lead to proactive learning and sharing of tips among teammates.

Team members choose their own tasks collaboratively each day. The Scrum Master, who facilitates these meetings, does not assign tasks.

title: Waste Through Multitasking
content:
The book outlines types of waste, starting with multitasking. Multitasking leads to failure—it's a myth. What we call multitasking is actually task switching, and each switch erodes focus.

People talking on the phone (even hands-free) are statistically more likely to get into car accidents. More passengers in the car also increase accident risk. We often overestimate our ability to multitask. Ironically, those who multitask most tend to be the worst at it.

This makes me think: are there tasks that _don’t_ suffer from multitasking? Like walking or breathing—these are automatic. So maybe the problem is attention-bound tasks, not background ones.

Multitasking might be more a symptom of poor systems than a necessity. If your workplace demands multitasking to stay productive, something’s broken. There's huge cognitive effort involved in switching contexts.

I'm also curious about the relationship between my phone usage—or lack of it—and my productivity. Does not using my phone help me focus more?

The book presents an idea that waste is a crime, breaking it down into three types: waste through unreasonableness, inconsistency, and poor outcomes. Examples include inventory waste, not doing it right the first time, overexertion, and emotional waste from unrealistic expectations.

title: Waterfall Method

# Waterfall Method

The waterfall method is a product management methodology where you develop the product in explicit steps. You start with product specifications, design, development, testing, and then release.

The author of SCRUM thinks this waterfall methodology doesn't work for a number of reasons:

- specifications and requirements are not stable
- there are inherent problems with product estimations that make a plan less effective as time goes on
- there is not iterative improvement, you finish the whole project at the end, little feedback during the process to see if you're on track.

It is my belief phone mindless technology usage is harmful and I am getting off of this by using a dumb phone.

Even now, I am not using my phone (because I have had a great habit of using it less, and I am writing instead. I am creating, using my brain, doing sometthing valuable.)
